-C.value: try { Use-Icinga; } catch { Write-Output 'The Icinga PowerShell Framework is either not installed on the system or not configured properly. Please check https://icinga.com/docs/windows for further details'; exit 3; }; Exit-IcingaPluginNotInstalled 'Invoke-IcingaCheckMSSQLPerfCounter'; exit Invoke-IcingaCheckMSSQLPerfCounter

7.description: The IP address or FQDN to the MSSQL server to connect to
7.caption: SqlHost

9.description: The name of a specific database to connect to. Leave empty to connect "globally"
9.caption: SqlDatabase

10.description:
Allows this plugin to use the credentials of the current PowerShell session inherited by
the user the PowerShell is running with. If this is set and the user the PowerShell is
running with can access to the MSSQL database you will not require to provide username
and password
10.caption: IntegratedSecurity

3.description: The critical threshold of the Performance Counter return values
3.caption: Critical

11.description: Disables the performance data output of this plugin
11.caption: NoPerfData

2.description: The warning threshold of the Performance Counter return values
2.caption: Warning

12.description:
Changes the behavior of the plugin output which check states are printed:
0 (default): Only service checks/packages with state not OK will be printed
1: Only services with not OK will be printed including OK checks of affected check packages including Package config
2: Everything will be printed regardless of the check state
12.caption: Verbosity

4.description:
List of Performance Counters specified by their full path (example '\SQLServer:Buffer Manager\Buffer cache hit ratio')
to fetch information for
4.caption: PerformanceCounter

6.description: The password for connecting to the MSSQL database as secure string
6.caption: SqlPassword

5.description: The username for connecting to the MSSQL database
5.caption: SqlUsername

8.description: The port of the MSSQL server/instance to connect to with the provided credentials
8.caption: SqlPort
